title: Jhin doesn't have a quadra kill line?

replies.body:
Would be cool to add.   

I can say why we didn't do it though.  The On_EnemyChamp_Kill lines were brand new then and untested by our team.   So we weren't entirely sure how/if they would work and more importantly how they would be received by players.  

So we didn't want to compound our bug risk and player perception risk further (For example by having the potential- quadra kill line playing over the pentakill line, the standard kill line, and announcer- line-  All playing  together at the same time 1% of time-- AND we couldn't even be sure players wouldn't prefer the announcer alone vs Jhin's voice!)
  
Our VO system is a bit byzantine and hacky -esp at that time -- and Jhin was made very, very quickly (about 75% of the time a normal champ takes)-- so there was going to be less bug fix time for him.  It was brought up as a cool idea-- but dropped because of the time/risk ≠ the perceived reward. 

  {{sticker:sg-soraka}}

One, single model does not take 5 months to make. Hell it wouldn't even take *one* month to make a good one - maybe a week or two at best. You've only got (at max) 4 abilities, so that would be relatively easy to do -- especially considering the basic movements the models do. And then when you consider how microscopic League is compared to other games that put out more content than you do... I really don't see the excuse, especially when you're pulling in billions a year.

Are you working on like 8 games at a time? I could see it taking a while then. But otherwise... I have to wonder at what the hell you do all day.
Yes, clearly all that's involved in making a game is making a 3D model.

1. Come up with an idea (no definite time frame)

2. Start a basic story and visual concept (no definite time frame)

3.  Make abilities (a day or two, maybe)

4. Make a model (few days to a week MAX)

5. Animate abiliites (a day or two)

6. Add sound (a day or two)

7. Add voice (depending on actor availability, no definite time frame, but usually within a week)

8.  Finish story (a day or two)

9. Release

Roughly in that order. 

Does that add up to 5-8 months? Especially for reworks, which already have an established role and lore identity.

On the one hand, I totally agree that the champion creation process, as Riot currently does it, takes a significantly longer period of time than the estimates listed above (I believe the stated time frame is 6 months per champ).

On the other hand, I remember a time in league where a new champion was released almost every patch, and I am fairly sure that Riot was a smaller company then, with a presumably smaller champion creation group (though I'm sure they had more than one team creating champs).

Granted, some of those champs were notoriously broken upon release - but usually just numerically rather than technically (obvious exceptions exist, like Azir, though I do believe he came after the champ ramp was over with).  It is also worth noting that champions were simpler then, with few of them adding new mechanics, effects, or technology to the game, so developing a kit was done in terms of what was already possible, not what would be cool to realize or expand on (Zoe has at least 2 new mechanics - sleep and walls adding length to skillshots.  Not sure if re-casting pladdlestar counts)

So yes, Riot has shown that, in the past (with an arguably lower production value - fewer VO lines, very few new things, etc) a team can churn out a champion much faster than currently.  I think it still took a team more than a few months to make a champ though.

The reason they were able to pump out champions that fast is because they were basically doing things at the speed the other guy was talking about. However, they sacrificed a lot of quality and depth for that speed. Most of the champions released during that time were very simple and pretty similar within classes. Lots of basic dashes, empowered auto attacks, etc.

Nowadays, they take a lot more time in order to make champions more unique and cohesive all around. Each champion has a lot more depth, especially when it comes to how their kit, story, visuals, and VO combine to make them into a complete, cohesive character.

I suppose, but now since there's so many champions and they have to code interactions with each champion for every new champion, as well as coding interactions with the new champion for every other champion, I think it makes sense that it takes longer for each champion. Add that to the fact that each champion has to be different from each one before it and it ends up taking a long while
You're an idiot and a liar.  No way you interned at NINTENDO and have these kinds of misconceptions about game design.  This is an entire career field you're blatantly insulting.

The longest part of the process is just thinking through an idea and coming up with a solid design. It could take a couple weeks, or it could take a couple months. There's no set timeframe.

But, when you tease a champ, you already have their identity locked in, and you know what they're going to do. At this point it's all production (modeling, animating, sound design, etc.), and none of that takes several months to do. The only thing that could potentially take a long time is getting a VA in, since they can be pretty booked at times -- and then hiring a VA for other language regions too.

League is a very, very small game, and the models aren't really super high quality or anatomically correct (they're made in perspective, and in the cartoony, stylized thing League does), so animating and programming isn't going to be some monumental undertaking. And Riot has hundreds of people working full-time jobs with a multi-billion dollar profit. So if some little company like Square Enix can pump out new content in FFXIV every 3 months, and if Arena Net can constantly update Guild Wars 2, then I see no reason why League can't rework cancerous old champs in a month or two per -- well, actually, the reason is to build up hype so more people spend money, but hey.

We had a hole in schedule for releases because Aurelion Sol got pushed back.  

Jhin came out well,  but he was stressful, and involved more drama than many champs-- also because the schedule we collapsed it meant I was working on three champs simultaneously-- not great for my personal homelife or stress level.  (I exploded a couple times)

For example most champs we write about 250 to 300 lines for them.   Jhin had over 600 recorded and about 800 written-- because I couldn't be sure about the final kit and animations.  So-- I just wrote lots and lots to cover every base I could see us exploring.  Then I and Kyle (sound designer) went through some long, rough days of cutting and figuring out what would work and where.  It worked.  But I can't help but feel he could have been even "more perfect."

--side note: I still miss the scary haiku's I wrote for him and we recorded-- but they didn't fit anywhere in his VO.
